title: Frontotemporal Degeneration: Epidemiology and Demographics
short_description: Clinical overview of frontotemporal degeneration prevalence, age of onset, and diagnostic challenges in the United States population.
long_description: This document provides essential epidemiological information about frontotemporal degeneration, highlighting its position as the second most common form of dementia in individuals under 65 years of age. The content covers key demographic data including the typical age of onset in the late 50s with a broad range of 20-80 years, prevalence estimates of 50,000-60,000 affected individuals in the United States, and the significant challenges in accurate diagnosis that contribute to underreporting of this neurodegenerative condition.
